---

Haptic sensors allow machines to "feel" like a human fingertip. They translate touch into digital signals. The term "haptic" originates from the Greek word "haptikos," meaning able to touch or perceive. In 1995, the first haptic feedback device was developed, revolutionizing virtual reality by enabling users to feel textures. Haptic sensors work by detecting pressure, vibration, and motion, converting these into electrical signals. For example, in smartphones, tiny motors create vibrations that mimic the sensation of pressing a physical button. The use of haptic technology in prosthetics has increased user satisfaction by 60%, allowing amputees to regain a sense of touch. Related fields include robotics, wearable technology, and virtual reality.
